item.title: A thing you should know if you are using multiple email accounts with `git send-email`
item.description:
In some case, we need to send patches that made by other people instead. git send-email command can know it by comparing the commit author information and mail sender's information. In that case, git send-email automatically add From: like pointing the real author of the patch in the body of the mail so that maintainers applying the patches can set the author information correctly.

For example, if “Alice alice@abc.com” has made a commit and “Bob bob@abc.com” formats the commit into a patch file and sends it, git send-email automatically adds From: Alice <alice@abc.com> line in the body of the mail. And, when a maintainer is applying the patch using git am, the patch is applied with author “Alice alice@abc.com”.

However, please note that git send-email notifies the situation by comparing the author information and the command caller's author information or given ‘–from’ option's email only, not considering real smtp email id.

For example, suppose that Alice has two email account, `alice@abc.com andalice@def.com. And, Alice wants to use alice@abc.comas her author email address, but need to send her patches usingdef.com` SMTP server. She might use below commands.

$ git config sendemail.smtpserver smtp.def.com
$ git config user.email "Alice <alice@abc.com>"
$ git commit -as -m 'the patch'
$ git format-patch HEAD^
$ git send-email the_patch

Because her git config is saying the user.email is `alice@abc.comand the patch is authored byalice@abc.com, git send-emailthinks same people is sending the patch and thus doesn't add the 'From:' line in the body of the mail. Of course,git send-emailtries to set thefrom of the mail asalice@abc.com`, but as the additionally specified ‘from’ information is usually (at least gmail does) ignored by the SMTP server, the maintainer will receive the mail saying author email is 'alice@def.com’ only.

Note that git send-email considers the email it tries to use as the from address, not the final one that SMTP server will use. Thus, this problem can be worked around in weird way using the --from option of the git send-email. In the above case, giving --from "Alice <alice@def.com>" option to git send-email makes the command to think the sender is not the author (alice@abc.com) and as a result, it adds the From: line in the body.

Also, please note that adding --from option does not always add the From: line in the body. Rather than that, it can even hide the From: line you intended to add, if you give the address that same with the commit's author, regardless of what SMTP server you use.

I was also recently made this mistakes and confused.
